title: Skeldon23 model forced wake up implementation
Breslow13 model
text:
We implemented the melatonin supression model from Breslow et al.¬†2013 (Breslow et al. 2013) that expands and improves a previous model (St Hilaire et al. 2007). The circadian part of the model is given by:
\[
\frac{dn}{dt} = 60 \left[ \alpha (1-n) - \beta n \right]
\]
where
\[
\alpha = \alpha_0 \left( \frac{I}{I_0} \right)^p \frac{I}{I + I_1}
\]

üö® In the article, the multiplication by 60 on \(\frac{dn}{dt}\) is missing

\[
\frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{1}{\kappa} \left[ x_c + \gamma \left( \frac{x}{3} + \frac{4x}{3} - \frac{256}{105} x^7 \right) + B + \eta M \right]
\]
\[
\frac{dx_c}{dt} = \frac{1}{\kappa} \left\{ \frac{B x_c}{3} - x \left[\left( \frac{24}{f \tau_c} \right)^2  + K B \right] - \xi M \right\}
\]

üö® In the article, the brackets after \(-x\) are missing, which is not correct based on Hilaire07 and Jewett00 from circadian

where
\[
M = \frac{M_{\text{max}}}{1 + \exp(\frac{H_{\text{sat} - H_2}}{\sigma})}
\]
Melatonin dynamics are given by
\[
\frac{dH_{1}}{dt} = - \beta_{IP} H_{1} + A(\phi) (1 - mB) S(H1, B)
\]
\[
\frac{dH_{2}}{dt} = \beta_{IP} H_{1} - \beta_{CP} H_{2} + \beta_{AP} H_{3}
\]
\[
\frac{dH_{3}}{dt} = - \beta_{AP} H_{3}
\]
where \(H_{1}\) is the pineal melatonin, \(H_{2}\) is the plasma melatonin, and \(H_{3}\) is the exogenous melatonin. Also
\[
\phi = \tan^{-1} \left( \frac{x}{x_c} \right)
\]

üö® Note that this is different from (St Hilaire et al. 2007; Abeysuriya et al. 2018) where they do \(\tan^{-1}(x_c/x)\).

\[
S(H_1, B) =  
\begin{cases}
  0 & \text{if} \ \ \ H_1 < 0.001 \ \ \text{and} \ \ (1 - mB) < 0 \\
  1 & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}
\]
the latter being a function to avoid negative values of \(H_1\) for sudden spikes in light. Melatonin synthesis is given by
\[
A(\phi) =
\begin{cases}
  a\left[ \frac{1 - e^{-\delta M_{2\pi}(\phi_{\text{on} - \phi})}}{1 - e^{-\delta M_{2\pi}(\phi_{\text{on}} - \phi_{\text{off}})}} \right] & \text{if} \ \ \ \phi < \phi_{\text{on}} \ \ \ \ \text{and} \ \ \ \ \phi > \phi_{\text{off}} \\
  ae^{-r M_{2\pi}(\phi_{\text{on} - \phi_{\text{off}}})} & \text{if} \ \ \  \phi_{\text{on}} < \phi < \phi_{\text{off}}
\end{cases}
\]
where \(M_{2\pi}\) is the modulo function.

üö® The value of the parameter \(K\) is not on the article but it can be taken to be 0.55 based on Jewet99 and Hilaire07


üö® Parameters on the paper are given in units of seconds. So we have to convert them to hours to match all the previous models on circadian. We multiplied \(\beta_{IP}\), \(\beta_{CP}\), \(\beta_{AP}\), and \(a\) by 3600.


üö® Phase thresholds on the paper are given outside the range \([-\pi, \pi]\) but our phase calculation lies within that range. So we do \(\hat{\phi_{\text{on}}} = \phi_{\text{on}} - 2\pi\) (same for \(\phi_{\text{off}}\))



Code
model = Breslow13()
trajectory = model.integrate(time, input=light)

x = trajectory.states[:, 0]
xc = trajectory.states[:, 1]
H1 = trajectory.states[:, 3]
H2 = trajectory.states[:, 4]
phase = np.arctan2(x, xc)

fig, axs = plt.subplots(3, 1, sharex=True, figsize=(12, 8))

# x, xc, and light
p_x = axs[0].plot(time, x, label='x')
p_xc = axs[0].plot(time, xc, label='xc')
light_changes = np.diff(light)
light_on = np.where(light_changes > 0)[0]
light_off = np.where(light_changes < 0)[0]
light_off = np.append(light_off, len(light) - 1)
for on, off in zip(light_on, light_off):
    axs[0].axvspan(time[on], time[off], color='yellow', alpha=0.4)
yellow_patch = plt.Rectangle((0, 0), 1, 1, fc="yellow", alpha=0.4)
axs[0].legend([p_x[0], p_xc[0], yellow_patch], ['x', 'xc', 'Light'],
              loc='upper left')
axs[0].set_ylabel('Circadian state (a.u.)')

# phase
axs[1].plot(time, phase, label='Phase')
axs[1].axhline(y=model.phi_on, color='gray', linestyle='--',)
axs[1].axhline(y=model.phi_off, color='gray', linestyle='--',)
places_on_1 = phase < model.phi_on
places_on_2 = phase > model.phi_off
places_on = np.where(np.logical_and(places_on_1,
                                    places_on_2))[0]
synthesis_on = np.zeros_like(phase)
synthesis_on[places_on] = 1.0
synthesis_changes = np.diff(synthesis_on)
on_places = np.where(synthesis_changes > 0)[0]
off_places = np.where(synthesis_changes < 0)[0]
for on, off in zip(on_places, off_places):
    axs[1].axvspan(time[on], time[off], color='gray', alpha=0.4)
for on, off in zip(light_on, light_off):
    axs[1].axvspan(time[on], time[off], color='yellow', alpha=0.4)
gray_patch = plt.Rectangle((0, 0), 1, 1, fc="gray", alpha=0.4)
axs[1].legend([gray_patch], ['Synthesis on'], loc='upper left')
axs[1].set_ylabel('Phase ' + r'$(\tan^{-1}(x/x_c))$')
axs[1].set_yticks(np.linspace(-np.pi, np.pi, 5))
axs[1].set_yticklabels(['$-\pi$', '$-\pi/2$', '0', '$\pi/2$', '$\pi$'])

# melatonin
axs[2].plot(time, H1, label='Pineal')
axs[2].plot(time, H2, label='Plasma')
for on, off in zip(light_on, light_off):
    axs[2].axvspan(time[on], time[off], color='yellow', alpha=0.4)
axs[2].legend(loc='upper left')
axs[2].set_xlabel('Time (hours)')
axs[2].set_ylabel('Melatonin (pmol/L)')
plt.show()





Model simulation





üö® We are getting really low values of peak melatonin (based on (St Hilaire et al. 2007) it should be more around 300). We need to find out why.





References

Abeysuriya, Romesh G., Steven W. Lockley, Peter A. Robinson, and Svetlana Postnova. 2018. ‚ÄúA Unified Model of Melatonin, 6-Sulfatoxymelatonin, and Sleep Dynamics.‚Äù Journal of Pineal Research 64 (4): e12474. https://doi.org/10.1111/jpi.12474.


Breslow, Emily R., Andrew J. K. Phillips, Jean M. Huang, Melissa A. St. Hilaire, and Elizabeth B. Klerman. 2013. ‚ÄúA Mathematical Model of the Circadian Phase-Shifting Effects of Exogenous Melatonin.‚Äù Journal of Biological Rhythms 28 (1): 79‚Äì89. https://doi.org/10.1177/0748730412468081.


St Hilaire, Melissa A., Claude Gronfier, Jamie M. Zeitzer, and Elizabeth B. Klerman. 2007. ‚ÄúA Physiologically Based Mathematical Model of Melatonin Including Ocular Light Suppression and Interactions with the Circadian Pacemaker.‚Äù Journal of Pineal Research 43 (3): 294‚Äì304. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1600-079X.2007.00477.x.

title: Effect of evening light on sleep
text:
Introduction
Mathematical modeling can help us understand how evening light affects our sleep. Throughout this document we use the Skeldon23() model from the circadian package. The model tells us how the circadian state and sleep homeostat evolve over time. The only input to the model is the light received at each timepoint:


Code
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from circadian.lights import LightSchedule

dt = 0.01 # hours
time = np.arange(0, 48, dt)
schedule = LightSchedule.Regular(1000.0, 6.0, 22.0)
light = schedule(time)

plt.plot(time, light)
plt.xlabel('Time (hours)')
plt.ylabel('Light intensity')
plt.show()





Light schedule






Code
from circadian.models import Skeldon23
model = Skeldon23()
trajectory = model.integrate(time, input=light)
x = trajectory.states[:, 0]

plt.plot(time, x)
plt.xlabel('Time (hours)')
plt.ylabel('Circadian state (a.u.)')
plt.show()

title: Skeldon23 model on Chang14 light schedule
text:
We did simulations for 125 parameter sets:

mu_values = np.linspace(17.5, 19.5, 5)
delta_values = np.linspace(5.0, 9.0, 5)
chi_values = np.linspace(7.0, 11.0, 5)

we select only those with a sleep duration that is greater than 6.5 hours, leaving us with 61 parameter sets. The distribution of sleep duration is shown below:









For each of these parameter sets, we simulate the model under three light schedules:

Regular
Chang14 with eBook on the first week (book on the second week)
Chang14 with eBook on the second week (book on the first week)

We can analyze the sleep onset for each simulation condition:



























As expected the regular condition has no change in sleep onset across days (it does between different simulations). For the Chang14 light schedule, we see that the sleep onset varies over the two weeks. When the eBook is on the first week (days 2-6), sleep onset remains relatively constant for that first week. However when reading is done with a book (days 8-12), the sleep onset starts to decrease. On the contrary, when the eBook is on the second week, sleep onset starts to decrease at first (book reading), and then increases (eBook reading).
There are many parameter sets that have a regular sleep onset that is close or equal to 22 hours (time the lights go off). Those sets tend to have little to no change when simulated under the Chang14 light schedules:










Difference in sleep onset between book and ebook days
As in [@chang_evening_2015], we plot the sleep latency (sleep_onset - 22.0) for each reading condition on the last day of reading:









Additionally, we calculate the sleep onset difference (within each simulation) between the last day of each reading condition:











Phase shift between book and ebook days
Let‚Äôs check how different the circadian state is for the different schedules on day 6 (plotting all simulated parameter sets):









It is surprising that there isn‚Äôt a spread between circadian states for different parameter sets, they are all on top of each other. On the other hand, if we plot the sleep pressure, we see a spread consistent with the spread in sleep onset times:









Why is this the case?
I think the reason is because of the way the sleep homeostat is implemented. The only way that the sleep homeostat can affect the circadian state is by switching to sleep at a moment when the light is greater than zero. If this happens, the input light to the circadian model goes to zero. However, in these simulations we are forcing the model to be awake when the light is on, so the light schedule is the same for all simulations. This means that the circadian state is the same for all simulations.
The only thing that can change the circadian state is changing the schedule, which does affect the final result as seen on the circadian state plot.
Therefore we can only obtain two values for the phase shift between book and eBook days, one for each schedule:
















The phase shift (calculated as the CBTmin difference between each condition) is 44.40 min for the eBook first condition and 14.40 min for the eBook second condition.
Let‚Äôs check if this is true for all parameter sets:
